awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Digital therapeutic virtual reality tool to address social isolation and improve geriatric care (COVID-19)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a technology to support social-emotional health by fostering co-presence, defined as a sense of being together in a virtual environment analogous to person-to-person physical interaction. Loneliness can be debilitating and have detrimental impact on patients aged 65 and over, causing an estimated $7 billion in Medicare costs associated with the effects of morbidity and mortality factors, such as dementia, heart disease, stroke, and depression. The recent COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted both the challenges and opportunities of digital tools in fostering connections associated with mental and physical health. The proposed virtual reality solution and the emerging digital therapeutics sector can address significant challenges faced by hospitals, assisted living care facilities, and mental health facilities, improving clinical outcomes.  The findings of this project are expected to impact other human interaction contexts, such as training, education, and others.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project advances translation of digital therapeutic tools to foster co-presence.  The project compares physiological and psychological markers between pairs of individuals in both real and virtual contexts in search of significant markers for co-presence. Objectives include development of a custom virtual reality application and collection of quantitative data on pairs of individuals interacting in three social contexts. Proposed research will evaluate the degree to which virtual reality fosters co-presence and focus on specific algorithms and design choices as significant drivers of co-presence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Phase I NSF project addressed the unprecedented and lethal loneliness epidemic that the United States, and the world, face. In 2021, the World Health Organization recognized isolation and loneliness as a global epidemic. Increased rates of loneliness in senior citizens have reached particularly concerning heights and further place the health of elders at risk. Studies estimate as many as 43% of adults over 60 report they are lonely, and that persistent loneliness is as lethal as smoking 15 cigarettes a day. This year alone the United States government will spend over 7 billion dollars to combat the effects of acute isolation and loneliness in senior citizens. These lonely and isolated seniors are more likely to develop heart disease, stroke, dementia, and depression; and they are 50% more likely to die early. The VRTogether virtual reality platform is designed to address the loneliness epidemic by solving the two main problems that plague current attempts to reduce loneliness in older adults 1) effectiveness, and 2) scalability. 

The project outcomes of this Phase I NSF SBIR award were the following: 1) the development of the VRTogether prototype and Co-presence Engine, a next-tier virtual reality system that mimics physical contact and provides meaningful social experiences and activities, and 2) the establishment of  the feasibility of VRTogether as a digital health technology capable of reducing social isolation and loneliness, with a particular focus on the senior population. We conducted research with 24 pairs of individuals including 12 pairs of older adult, and our research demonstrated that interacting socially in VRTogether creates a similar sensation to interacting in the same physical space and our findings demonstrated that social collaboration and teamwork is more linked between participants when interacting in VRTogether compared to a control VR environment, or even when participants shared the same physical space.  Importantly, our results also determined that participants expressed higher rates of psychological connection in VRTogether. Specifically, participants' ratings of teamwork and collaboration were most aligned with their partners in VRTogether, compared to both the VR Control and Real-Life environments. Additionally, we received a supplemental I-Corp grant with which we completed the I-Corp program and have over the course of the project interviewed 175+ senior care professionals, health care professionals, and older adults. 

Success during Phase I has provided traction towards the full development of VRTogether as an innovative and unique solution that stands alone in the current technology ecosystem with the potential to reduce financial burden on facilities and families and reduce government spending to increase the economic competitiveness of the United States, and most importantly, improve the health and wellbeing of the US aging population.
